howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.
Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."
 < this message is answering to > 
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' responsibility to take precautions causes the likelihood of a severe reaction to manifest and affect their job performance?

Do you have any scientific sources that support the claim that the responsibility to take precautions for a severe allergy lies solely with the individual or their caretaker, rather than with airlines or other entities?

If the airlines can have precautions in place for passengers with severe tree nut allergies, would they not also have a responsibility to take precautions for passengers with other allergies, such as peanut allergies?

If we should rely on personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy, why do we need to implement a ban on peanuts in public spaces if they can take precautions?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of any of the pieces influence the decisions they make about whether to create the digital widget or which digital widget to create?
Do you have a scientific source that confirm that peanuts are indeed a nutritious food and universally enjoyed, rather than being a source of deathly allergies?
If peanuts are so nutritious and almost universally enjoyed, why are parents so readily swayed by the idea that peanuts are a deathly allergy risk, when in reality, the risk is incredibly low?

If peanuts are so nutritious and universally enjoyed, then why are people who have a medically diagnosed severe allergy to peanuts advised to never leave the house, suggesting a complete avoidance of a food that is considered one of the best on the planet?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: What if the peanut allergy sufferers are forced to choose between flying on flights where peanuts are served, which could cause their allergy to manifest and affect their job performance?

Do you have a scientific source that confirms that the air circulation system can effectively remove peanut dust from the air to a level that prevents life-threatening reactions in individuals with peanut allergies?

If the presence of peanuts on flights poses a significant health risk to individuals with peanut allergies, why should they not be treated with the same level of caution and accommodation as smokers were treated before the implementation of smoke-free flights?

If peanut dust can be airborne and cause a life-threatening reaction, why can't the same logic be applied to smoking, which also produces airborne particles that can cause health issues, and therefore, shouldn't smoking also be prohibited on flights?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: What if the presence of peanuts on planes causes anaphylactic reactions in children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002, as claimed in the provided text?

If peanuts pose a unique risk to allergic individuals on planes due to their ability to break into fine pieces and become airborne, why would the same risks not also apply to other foods that can also break into fine pieces and become airborne, such as cheese or crackers?

If peanut allergies pose a unique risk and EpiPens are not 100% effective, then why should the airline industry not take proactive measures to eliminate the presence of peanuts on planes, rather than relying solely on emergency interventions to save lives?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of space and ergonomic design in economy class seats causes passengers to experience back and leg pain, affecting their overall travel experience and potentially leading to a decrease in airline satisfaction ratings?

Do you have any expert opinions or studies that support the claim that the lack of space in airline seats is the top issue that airlines need to address, rather than other concerns such as in-flight entertainment or food quality?

If the airlines prioritize improved leg room and comfort as a top issue, would this not be a significant factor in transforming the experience of air travel from a necessary evil to a more enjoyable and eagerly anticipated one?

If airlines can prioritize passenger comfort and space by implementing ergonomic and comfortable designs, then why do they continue to prioritize profit over passenger well-being by not addressing the lack of space in their aircraft?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's current policies cause their customers to choose not to travel with their pets, thereby affecting the airline's revenue and customer loyalty?

Do you have any scientific sources or studies that confirm that allowing pets to travel in the cabin with their owners, secured by seat belts, is more safe and beneficial than the current cargo system?
If airline companies can accommodate humans with special needs and requirements, why can't they also accommodate pets with similar needs and requirements?

If you value the convenience and companionship of traveling with your dog, then why would you not expect airlines to prioritize your needs and accommodate your pet's travel requirements in the cabin rather than solely relying on cargo?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: What if the amount of media coverage Bernie Sanders is receiving is the cause that affects his chances at getting the nomination?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms that a politician's chances of getting the nomination can be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting?

If a relatively unknown candidate like Bernie Sanders, who was initially overlooked by the media, can gain significant attention and become a competitive candidate, would it not be reasonable to expect that a similarly unknown candidate, like O'Malley, could also gain attention and become a competitive candidate?

If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about, then why did O'Malley's relatively low media coverage not impact his chances in the same way it did for some other candidates?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: What if the new rules requiring airlines to inform passengers every 30 minutes about flight delays cause a decrease in anxiety issues among passengers?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the current 3-hour rule for flight delays is too long and should be reduced to 2 hours, as you mentioned in your personal anecdote?
If people are people no matter where they are, would this not mean that flight delays should be treated similarly across all airports, airlines, and destinations?

If you believe that people should be informed every 30 minutes to alleviate frustration, then why do you think that the current 3-hour limit is still too long, despite your personal experience of being stranded on a plane three times?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of equal airtime for the Green Party candidates on major news networks causes their ideas to be misunderstood or misrepresented, affecting their ability to gain traction in the general election?

Do you have a scientific source that confirms that the Green Party Presidential Debate should not be given equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election?

If a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public, why would privately owned networks not be obligated to give them equal time compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election?
If a person has the right to express their views in public places, why should private networks not be required to provide them equal time to express those views?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: What if the first debate is limited to five people, and every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate?

Do you have a scientific source that confirm that every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate to a greater degree than others?
If the first debate was already limited to five people, would the 171 people who have filed the paperwork with the FEC not deserve their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate?

If we have limited the first debate to five people, then are we implying that the other 166 candidates who have filed the paperwork with the FEC do not deserve their fair shot at expressing themselves?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: What if the imposition of common sense regulations would cause airlines to lose their competitive edge, potentially affecting their ability to provide better service to customers and level the playing field?

Do you have any scientific source that confirms that regulation-driven cost-cutting in the airline industry would lead to better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which airlines compete?

If commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits, would this not be an argument for the need for external intervention to level the playing field?

If airline competition is driven solely by cost-cutting measures that prioritize profits over passenger needs, then how can imposing common sense regulations truly level the playing field and promote better service to customers?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of food and drink options causes passengers to become uncomfortable and unhealthy, and thus affect their overall travel experience?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that passengers should only be offered a bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice, rather than more substantial food and drink options, during extended periods of sitting on a plane?
If airline passengers are expected to sit for over six hours at the gate before takeoff, why would they not be offered more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water as a standard offering?
If passengers are forced to wait for an extended period, should the airline still deny them access to food and drink, considering the potential health risks associated with prolonged fasting?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: What if allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not cause their hunger to manifest and affect their behavior during the flight?

Do you have a scientific source that confirm that passengers should be allowed off the plane into a holding area to move around before the normal serving point, especially considering the potential health risks of excessive delay in serving meals?

If passengers are allowed to move around in a holding area without access to food and drink, wouldn't it resemble what are commonly referred to as races, where individuals are allowed to participate in certain events without receiving the same benefits as others?

If passengers are not given access to food and drink while waiting in the holding area, then why should they be expected to wait for the dinner to be served at the normal point in the flight, especially when on a connecting flight and there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: What if the airline industry's reliance on discriminatory ticketing practices causes passengers to lose trust in the system and affect their willingness to book flights in the future?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that airline tickets should not be considered a form of lottery, where the price of the ticket does not guarantee the provision of the service?
If airline tickets are not lottery tickets, would it not be more logical for airlines to guarantee that passengers will reach their destinations, regardless of their ticket price or miles used?

If airline tickets are not lottery tickets, then why should passengers be treated as if they are buying a gamble, where the outcome of their travel is uncertain and dependent on their ticket price or frequent flyer miles?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of incentives for airlines to schedule properly causes them to discriminate against lower-fared passengers, affecting their ability to reach their destinations as promised?

Do you have any scientific source that supports the claim that airlines are treating passengers as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports, and that this behavior is not a result of passenger choice but rather a result of airline manipulation?

If airlines are required to compensate passengers for being bumped, why would they not be incentivized to schedule properly, especially when it is the airline who sets the agreed price or miles for a seat?

If airlines are incentivized to prioritize passengers who paid more, then are they not also incentivizing the very behavior they claim to be trying to eliminate by allowing passengers to be bumped for those who paid less?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of knowledge about peanut presence on flights causes passengers with peanut allergies to experience severe reactions, affecting their health and overall flight experience?

If airlines are required to inform passengers about peanuts being served, would they not also be required to inform passengers about other potential allergens, such as nuts, gluten, or soy, that may be present on the flight?
Should airlines inform passengers about peanut presence on flights before they purchase tickets, rather than relying on in-flight announcements?

You learn a lot from financial disclosure
That I can tell you
you should go down and take a look at that

a lot of friends of mine that know my business

the $ 650 is n't even on that
it 's not $ 650
It 's much less than that
I could give you a list of banks

These are very fine institutions
very fine banks

I am very underleveraged
I have a great company

the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way

If Trump's financial situation is so stable, why does he need to downplay his debt and claim he's underleveraged when the report actually shows he owes $650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks?

TRUMP_114_2.input:
TRUMP: "our country 's a mess
it 's one thing to have $ 20 trillion in debt
Our airports are like from a third world country
You land at LaGuardia , you land at Kennedy , you land at LAX , you land at Newark , and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible—you come in from China , you see these incredible airports
we 've become a third world country
our bridges are good
everything 's in great shape
our airports
the worst of all things has happened
We owe $ 20 trillion
we 're a mess
We have n't even started
we 've spent $ 6 trillion in the Middle East
according to a report that I just saw
Whether it 's 6 or 5
 it looks like it 's 6
we could have rebuilt our country twice
it 's really a shame
it 's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem
Our country has tremendous problems
We 're a debtor nation
We 're a serious debtor nation
we have a country that needs new roads , new tunnels , new bridges , new airports , new schools , new hospitals
we don't have the money
it 's been squandered on so many of your ideas"

cqs.cq: What if the country's problems, such as its debt and infrastructure issues, are a direct result of the politicians' decisions, rather than the country's inherent characteristics, and thus, does this mean that the politicians are the cause of the country's problems?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the United States is a third world country in terms of airport infrastructure, as opposed to the anecdotal evidence presented by President Trump?

If the United States is considered a "third world country" due to its airport infrastructure, why would that not be a reflection of a broader societal issue rather than a solely partisan one, as suggested by Trump?

If the country is indeed a mess and in such a poor state that it needs new roads, new tunnels, new bridges, new airports, new schools, new hospitals, then why have the politicians, like Secretary Clinton, who have been in power for so long, failed to address these problems and instead squandered the money on other priorities?

TRUMP_121_1.input:
TRUMP: "I do think it's time
it's all words
it's all sound bites
I built an unbelievable company
Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world
real estate assets anywhere in the world
beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places
It's an unbelievable company
on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there
when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation
if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws
you've been there a long time,
I take advantage of the laws of the nation
I'm running a company
My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies
that's what I do
what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me"

cqs.cq: What if the fact that Trump took advantage of the laws of the nation to build his company and increase his wealth has caused him to become so wealthy that he believes his obligation is to do well for himself, his family, his employees, and his companies, rather than serving the greater good?
Do you have any scientific source that confirms that women are more likely to be narcissistic sociopaths to a greater degree than men?

If Trump claims that he built an "unbelievable company" with real estate assets anywhere in the world, but also admits to taking advantage of the laws of the nation, doesn't that imply that he believes the laws are flawed, rather than a reflection of his own success?

TRUMP_121_2.input:
TRUMP: "I'll give you an example
We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House
if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another
we're opening the Old Post Office
I'm a year ahead of schedule
that's what this country should be doing
We build roads
they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost

we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy
The Trump International is way under budget
way ahead of schedule

cqs.cq: What if the lack of effective management and the influence of special interests cause the budget to be mismanaged and affect the country's ability to build roads and acquire military products?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that Trump's assertion that his company's projects are completed "way ahead of schedule" and "way under budget" is accurate?

If Trump's private business projects, like the Trump International, can be completed under budget and ahead of schedule, why would the government projects, like the Pennsylvania Avenue development, not be able to achieve similar results?
If Trump's construction projects are consistently under budget and ahead of schedule, then why should we assume that his proposed infrastructure projects for the country would be any different?

TRUMP_125_1.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this
Is this a war-torn country
What are we doing
we have to stop the violence

cqs.cq: What if the jobs in infrastructure, in advanced manufacturing, innovation and technology, clean, renewable energy, and small business, which are key to building an economy that works for everyone, not just those at the top, are ones that cause their illness to manifest and affect their job performance?
Do you have any scientific source that supports the claim that women's work being paid equally is a key indicator of a country being fair and prosperous?

If the central question in this election is what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we'll build together, would that not also imply that the economic policies proposed by the speaker should prioritize the needs of the next generation, such as his granddaughter, who are currently at the beginning of their lives and careers?

If we are to build an economy that works for everyone, then why does the focus on small business jobs seem to be prioritized over addressing the systemic issues of unequal pay and profit-sharing that affect the broader workforce?
